I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.    Economic growth in Asia and the Pacific has been impressive over the past 15 years, 
with strongly positive impacts on poverty reduction. But it has come at an environmental cost. 
Rising pollution in rapidly expanded urban areas and widening degradation of natural resource 
systems threaten public health and undermine economic productivity.  
 
2.    There is growing pressure within most countries of the region to alter economic patterns 
so  that  they  can  be  environmentally  sustainable,  but  the  investment  requirements  will  be 
enormous. Demand for infrastructure of all types is growing rapidly in the Asia-Pacific region, 
but in recent years it has become clear that a significant portion of this investment will be 
needed to address the widening environmental problems arising from rapid growth. Bottlenecks 
imposed by poor infrastructure are considered to be a significant constraint on future growth, 
especially foreign investment.  
 
3.    Public financing will be important as a catalyst but private capital will also be required to 
meet investment demands. Public policy reform is needed to create the enabling conditions to 
induce this investment and take advantage of energy opportunities. Economic, environmental, 
and  trade  policies  need  adjustment  to  set  priorities  for  targeted  public  investments  and 
encourage private financing. 
 
4.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) can play an important role in helping to meet these 
environmental investment needs. It can work with developing member countries (DMCs) to help 
them devise appropriate policies—based on different priorities and investment climates—that 
will  create  the  policy  and  institutional  conditions  conducive  to  investment.  ADB  also  can 
encourage enhanced regional cooperation to promote environmental sustainability while forming 
partnerships with governments and the private sector to make catalytic investments that lead by 
example.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  for  the  technical  assistance1 (TA)  is  in 
Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.    Economic development and poverty alleviation in Asia and the Pacific are increasingly 
constrained by deteriorating environmental quality and degradation of natural resources—often 
as a direct negative side effect of the region’s economic expansion. Although the situation 
varies by country, this is leading to greatly increased demands on both public and private 
institutions to improve environmental quality, especially the need for expanded investment in 
infrastructure  and  environmental  management  systems.  However,  the  breakneck  speed  of 
economic growth in some developing countries has shown that environmental institutions are 
not  nimble  enough  to  keep  pace  with  expanding  pollution  and  resource  degradation,  and 
environmental quality is in decline throughout much of the Asia-Pacific region. 
 
6.    Investments are needed to remediate the negative economic and environmental impacts 
of the past and ensure that future development is sustainable. Remediation investments needed 
include those to (i) clean up polluted rivers, (ii) control urban air pollution, (iii) deal with solid 
waste  management,  (iv)  locate  and  mitigate  the  impacts  of  previously  disposed  toxic  and 
hazardous wastes, and (v) restore damaged ecosystems. Efforts also are called for to put 
development on a more sustainable path by (i) encouraging greater use of clean and renewable 
energy  resources;  (ii)  providing  efficient  public  transport  systems;  (iii)  encouraging  energy

2   
efficiency  and  sustainable  energy  use  patterns  by  consumers  and  businesses;  and 
(iv) establishing sustainable patterns of use for renewable resources such as forests, fisheries, 
and wetlands. In particular, increasing attention is being given to reducing waste, and reusing 
and recycling resources and products—the so-called 3Rs—as the basis of a  “sound material-
cycle society” or “circular economy” in which both the consumption of natural resources and the 
environmental “footprint” from economic activity are lowered. A regional senior officials meeting 
on this subject is planned for March 2006, which will provide an opportunity for the TA to identify 
appropriate responses relating to environmental investment. 
 
7.    Several important opportunities appear to exist for promoting increased environmental 
investment. Particular attention needs to be paid to the adjustment of environmental policies, 
financing  arrangements,  and  trade  policies.  Environmental  policies  need  to  better  identify 
priorities  for  investment  and  work  with  public  investment  programs  to  justify  cleanup  and 
proactive expenditures. They also need to create incentives for complementary private capital 
flows into these areas. Financing opportunities can be realized through (i) removing of rigidities 
in the ability of municipalities to raise funds through bond markets or as borrowers in project 
financing;  and  (ii)  overcoming  constraints  on  information  flows  regarding  investment 
opportunities,  (iii)  addressing  weaknesses  in  domestic  capital  markets,  (iv)  reducing  legal 
restrictions on private equity investment, or (v) forming of public-private partnerships. Asia is on 
the cusp of capturing a significant portion of the global market for environmental goods and 
services. Trade policy needs to facilitate this by including measures to ensure that companies 
can  take  advantage  of  growing  “green”  markets,  including  the  free  interstate  flow  of 
environmentally beneficial goods and services. At the same time, country trade policies should 
not use lower environmental standards as a basis for attracting foreign investment.  
 
8.    The recently published Asian Environment Outlook 20052 suggests a range of positive 
environmental policy steps that governments can take to encourage increased private sector 
environmental performance and investment. Based on a growing body of experience, it shows 
that governments can use a blend of market-based instruments and voluntary measures—
backed by stronger enforcement of core environmental regulations—to help shape a predictable 
and fair environmental policy regime in the spirit of public-private partnership. In other cases, 
such as state leadership through green procurement practices, public policy needs to lead the 
way through example. ADB and other development partners are supporting dialogue on these 
issues among the countries of the region at the regional and subregional levels, through forums 
such as the recently launched Asian Environmental Compliance and Enforcement Network 
(AECEN). 
 
9.    New financing opportunities to support environmental investments abound. While limited 
experimentation with private investment has produced mixed results to date, the scope of 
demand is clearly beyond the ability of governments alone to respond. Green investment funds, 
such  as  the  recently  created  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  Environment  Fund,  are 
beginning  to  show  promise  on  a  relatively  small  scale,  but  the  experience  and  policy 
implications should be used to promote expanded and refined investment instruments. Financial 
institutions  are  gradually  improving  their  understanding  of  environmental  investment 
opportunities and the environmental dimensions of all investments. In partnership with the 
International Finance Corporation (IFC), ADB will enhance its training of financial intermediaries 
to  help  them  better  evaluate  the  merits  of  and  returns  from  environmental  investments. 
Opportunities to capture benefits from reductions in greenhouse gas emissions through the 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2005. Asian Environment Outlook 2005—Making Profits, Protecting Our Planet: Corporate Responsibility for 
Environmental Performance in Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

3
clean development mechanism (CDM) and other carbon markets offer yet another innovative 
approach worth expanding. There also would appear to be significant scope for widening private 
equity investment in socially and environmentally proactive companies through the creation of 
socially responsible investment (SRI) funds within the region. 
 
10.   ADB is an executing agency of the Global Environment Facility (GEF), which provides 
cofinancing for TA and investments that enable the realization of global environmental benefits. 
GEF seeks to employ innovative financing mechanisms to spur green investments through both 
public and private projects. For example, GEF funds have been used to overcome financial, 
technical,  and  institutional  barriers  to  the  development  and  eventual  commercialization  of 
technologies in renewable energy and energy efficiency, where these lead to reductions in 
greenhouse gas emissions.  
 
11.   To  further  accelerate  economic  growth  and  alleviate  poverty  in  the  region,  many 
countries are entering into bilateral and regional free trade agreements and promoting other 
forms  of  regional  economic  cooperation.  By  reducing  tariff  barriers,  countries  can  rely  on 
comparative  advantage  to  compete  internationally  and  attract  foreign  investment.  The 
environmental behavior of firms—especially those exporting to Europe and North America—is 
becoming an increasingly important part of consumer preferences and the trade policies of 
importing countries. This has led to the expanded use of eco-labels, certification systems3 and 
other measures to demonstrate that international standards are being met. While not the only 
factor, low regulatory costs can also enter into the decision-making equation regarding foreign 
investment. Regional economic integration should be constructed so that it triggers a “race to 
the  top”,  where  companies  move  beyond  compliance  to  establish  their  environmental 
credentials as a competitive marketing edge and see environmental goods and services as a 
potential growth industry. The alternative is for countries to compete with each other through 
offering the lowest environmental standards, resulting in a “race to the bottom”.  
 
12.  The member countries of the South Asia Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) 
have  recently  committed  themselves  to  a  freer  trade  regime,  with  environmental  side 
agreements  pending.  In  East  Asia,  the  current  evolution  of  bilateral  and  regional  trade 
agreements is expected to culminate in the creation of an East-Asian Economic Community 
(EAEC) by 2020 at the latest. EAEC will likely comprise the PRC, Japan, Republic of Korea, and 
the 10 member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Both the SAARC 
and EAEC processes of economic integration should have at least five types of effects: (i) 
structural—change in the sectoral composition of the countries’ economies; (ii) scale—change 
in the overall level of economic activity; (iii) composition—flow of products and services; (iv) 
technology—transfer of environmentally-friendly technologies or possibly “pollution havens”; and 
(v) regulatory—“locking-in” reform towards more market-friendly but stringent environmental 
regulation. These effects hold crucial implications for the environment, poverty alleviation, and 
sustainable development in the region and merit careful examination.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  that  governments,  the  private  sector  and/or  financial 
institutions of the region increase their investments in measures to improve environmental 
                                                 
3 The International Standards Organization (ISO) 14001 certification system has become the most commonly applied 
and recognized environmental management system.

4   
management. The regional TA’s outcome will be to enable interested governments, private 
sector groups, financial institutions and/or regional economic integration organizations to adopt 
environmental  policies  and  other  actions  to  take  advantage  of  opportunities  for  expanded 
investment in improved environmental management in Asia and the Pacific.4 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.   The TA is organized into three components, each responding to a key opportunity for 
increased environmental investment in the region, relating to environmental policy, financing, 
and trade.  
 
15.   Output 1. Environmental policy opportunities will be addressed by providing advisory 
support and capacity building to DMCs. Based on an assessment of DMC needs in this respect, 
specific country-level or subnational policy reforms will be chosen as examples to demonstrate 
benefits and best practices. Besides AECEN, other regional groupings and partners—including 
the Greater Mekong Subregion, Central Asian Regional Economic Cooperation mechanism, 
United Nations Centre for Regional Development, and United Nations Environment Program—
may  also  be  engaged  in  the  development  of  environmental  policy  approaches  to  induce 
investment and serve as conduits for dissemination of recommendations. Environmental policy 
reforms to be promoted may include the (i) simplification of regulations regarding private sector 
investment in environmental infrastructure, (ii) expanded use of market-based instruments, and 
(iii) promotion of materials reduction. Wider application of voluntary measures leading to public-
private  partnerships  also  will  be  encouraged,  potentially  including  the  (i)  organization  of 
investments  in  the  areas  of  waste  reduction,  reuse,  and  recycling  (3Rs);  (ii)  wastewater 
management; (iii) clean and renewable energy; (iv) energy efficiency; (v) air pollution control; 
(vi) solid waste management; and (vii) sustainable urban transport. 
 
16.   Output  2.  The  TA  also  will  examine  new  financing  opportunities  to  increase 
environmental investment, including new sources of capital. Analysis of promising measures will 
complement parallel efforts in the areas of urban infrastructure, GEF, energy efficiency, CDM 
and other carbon market instruments. Efforts will be made to expand investor interest and to 
identify ADB investment opportunities. In cooperation with ADB’s Private Sector Operations 
Department, consultations will be held with potential private investors to seek their views and 
possibly develop pilot projects or financial mechanisms demonstrating innovative approaches. 
The TA will explore prospects for enhanced cofinancing of ADB investments from a variety of 
sources, including non-sovereign borrowers, bilateral donors, the private sector, and the GEF. 
The  latter  offers  particular  opportunities  in  the  areas  of  clean  and  renewable  energy  and 
management  of  hazardous  wastes.  In  consultation  with  ADB’s  regional  and  private  sector 
departments, a selection of appropriate public and private sector projects in their early stages of 
preparation  will  be  chosen  as  pilots  for  development  and  application  of  recommended 
approaches to promoting increased environmental investment in the region. 
 
17.  Output  3.  With  respect  to  enhancing  trade  policy  opportunities  for  promoting 
environmental investment, the TA will primarily focus on the nascent EAEC as a model for 
regional economic integration and incorporation of environmental considerations into new trade 
regimes. A project on the Promotion of Sustainable Development in the Context of East Asia’s 
Regional Economic Integration is being funded by the Government of Japan and implemented 
through the Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES) in cooperation with a range of

5
partners.5 That project will examine country and regional policies in detail, using regional level 
quantitative and qualitative analysis and covering six countries: Japan, Republic of Korea, PRC, 
Indonesia, Thailand, and Viet Nam.6 The TA will work in partnership with IGES to draw other 
countries into the dialogue on and analysis of these issues. 
 
18.  The findings of the TA will be summarized in a unified report integrating elements from 
each of the key components. A range of other written outputs outlining new policy approaches 
and partnership arrangements to promote environmental investment also will be produced. 
These  will  be  developed  through  active  dialogue  with  partners  throughout  the  region  and 
disseminated through these same networks. The TA also will provide recommendations to ADB 
for enhancing its own operations in this area. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $400,000. The amount of $200,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program and $200,000 will be cofinanced by the 
Government of Finland and administered by ADB. The detailed cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will serve as the Executing Agency for the TA which will be implemented by its 
Environment and Social Safeguard Division. All consultants will be selected and recruited on an 
individual basis by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the recruitment of domestic consultants. Equipment 
will be purchased in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement.7 A total of 8 person-
months of international consultant support in the areas of policy, finance and trade will be 
required together with 15 person-months of domestic consultants. The consultants will submit 
inception reports, progress reports, and a draft final report suitable for subsequent publication in 
an integrated final TA report. The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The TA will 
commence in January 2006 and will be completed 18 months later.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Finland, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis for Promoting Environmental Investment 
in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
 
A.  International Consultants (8 person-months) 
 
1.  Senior Policy Analyst (5 person-months) 
 
1.  The senior policy analyst will be employed for a period of 5 months on an intermittent basis 
over the duration of the technical assistance (TA) to undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist with preparing and negotiating a Letter of Agreement with the Institute for 
Global Environmental Strategies (IGES) for its activities under the TA and assist 
with review of IGES outputs.  
 
(ii)  Work with developing member countries (DMCs) and regional partners to develop 
working relationships and select pilot activities relating to policy adjustments and 
other measures for promotion of environmental investments. 
 
(iii)  In cooperation with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) operational departments, 
review ADB’s current project portfolio from the standpoint of its engagement in 
environmentally beneficial infrastructure or other investments, and assist with the 
selection  of  pilot  investment  projects  for  developing  and  applying  TA 
recommendations. 
 
(iv)  Assist with the conduct of regional consultations on the subjects of the TA and in 
cooperation with TA partners. 
 
(v)  Assist with preparation of the TA inception, midterm, and integrated summary report 
as well as other reporting and communications, as assigned.  
 
2.  Environmental Financing Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
2.  The environmental financing specialist will be employed for a period of 2 months on an 
intermittent basis to undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Consult with operational departments of ADB and private sector parties and other 
partners  to  identify  key  financial  opportunities  for  enhanced  environmental 
investments in the region.  
 
(ii)  Prepare a report providing findings relating to opportunities identified in (i) and 
recommending measures to take advantage of them. 
 
(iii)  Work  with  ADB  operational  departments  to  develop  pilot  project  activities  to 
demonstrate  innovative  approaches  to  taking  advantage  of  these  financing 
opportunities.  
 
(iv)  Incorporate the findings of this analysis into both a stand-alone and integrated report 
on these subjects. 
 
(v)  Present the findings of the analysis to ADB and its partners and work with them to 
see that recommendations are adopted where feasible.

3.  Environmental Policy Specialist (1 person-month) 
 
3.  The environmental financing specialist will be employed for a period of 1 month on an 
intermittent basis to undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Consult with DMCs and other parties, as appropriate, to identify key opportunities 
for environmental adjustments to enhance environmental investments in the region.  
 
(ii)  Prepare  a  report  providing  findings  relating  to  these  opportunities  and 
recommending measures to take advantage of them. 
 
(iii)  Work with ADB operational departments to develop pilot policy measures related to 
TA  or  project  interventions  that  can  demonstrate  innovative  approaches  to 
capitalizing on these environmental policy opportunities.  
 
(iv)  Incorporate the findings of this analysis into both a stand-alone and integrated report 
on these subjects. 
 
(v)  Present the findings of the analysis to partners and work with them to see that 
recommendations are adopted where feasible. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultant: Environmental Policy Analyst (15 person-months) 
 
4.  The environmental policy analyst will be employed for a period of 15 months to undertake 
the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist the ADB TA manager and senior policy analyst with all aspects of the TA’s 
activities and administration. 
 
(ii)  Serve as principal liaison with the AECEN secretariat, IGES, and other partners with 
respect to cooperation under the TA. 
 
(iii)  Assist with the conduct of regional consultations on the subjects of the TA and in 
cooperation with TA partners. 
 
(iv)  Assist with preparation of TA inception, midterm, and integrated summary report as 
well as dissemination of findings.
